items.title: process_cmdline property removed from v2 process search results
items.body:
The change to the process search v2 API appears to have removed the `process_cmdline` from Process search results. The only option to now get this information is via `process.summary.process['process_cmdline']` which means performing an additional query based on the `/api/investigate/v1/orgs/{org_key}/processes/summary` API endpoint for each search result that's returned. This slows things down significantly.

In addition, the use of `/api/investigate/v1/orgs/{org_key}/processes/summary` by the Python API (via `process.summary.process['process_cmdline']`) often can not find the requested `process_guid` returned in the Process search results, which results in errors like the following: 

```json
Received 404 (Object Not Found) for https://defense-prod05.conferdeploy.net/api/investigate/v1/orgs/ORGKEY/processes/summary?process_guid=ORGKEY-013e64dd-000029f0-00000000-1d64514443470e9: 
{
    "message":"Resource does not exist",
    "translation_key":"threathunter_resource_does_not_exist",
    "translation_format_values":null
}
```

Manually checkingt the v1 REST API summary endpoint confirms that in the cases where those errors occur the Process with the `process_guid` that is returned from the v2 process search can not be found and throws a 404 error as a result.

Can `process_cmdline` be readded as a field to the v2 process search results so Python scripts do not require the use of additional (expensive) `process.summary.process['process_cmdline']` calls?

items.title: [BUG] CBR Alert unique_id Not Exposed to GET Query
items.body:
**I am seeing this behaviour on: (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: Windows
 - Carbon Black Product: CB EDR (Response)
 - Python Version: 2.7

**Describe the bug**
It is not possible to query an alert by unique_id. While each Alert unique_id is exposed when iterating through the results of alerts from a cb.select(Alert) query, attempting to provide the unique_id to the select method returns a nearly empty Alert object, containing only a unique_id data member. Attempting to where() on an Alert select with a valid unique_id returns a 400 "query_syntax_error" from the API.

**Steps to Reproduce**
```python
alert_unique_id = c.select(Alert).first().unique_id  # Find a legitimate Alert unique_id
print (str(alert_unique_id))  # Print alert_unique_id
alert_by_id_1 = c.select(Alert, alert_unique_id)  # Select the alert from the unique_id
print (str(alert_by_id_1))  # Print alert selected from ID - notice it returns only alert_unique_id
alert_by_id_2 = c.select(Alert).where("unique_id:" + str(alert_unique_id))  # Try a where on alert_unique_id instead
print (len(alert_by_id_2))  # Print alert_by_id_2 length to see if it has 1 or more elements, ServerError thrown

# Example: HTTP GET /api/v2/alert?cb.urlver=1&facet=false&q=unique_id%3A92dacdf2-57aa-4276-8fba-871725b6d6ae&rows=1&start=0 took 0.043s (response 400)

 ```

**Expected behavior**
Both of the following would return a single alert object identical to what was returned from c.select(Alert).first()
```python
# Assume alert_unique_id is a valid Alert unique_id
alert_by_id_1 = c.select(Alert, alert_unique_id)
alert_by_id_2 = c.select(Alert).where("unique_id:" + str(alert_unique_id))
 ```

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Additional context**
The inability to do this restricts pulling single Alerts by their ID, which would be useful for product integrations.
This follows emails I had with CB Developer Relations.

items.title: Cb ThreatHunter _search() function does not yield the correct num_available results
Mismatch in yaml keys
items.body:
For the file present in the location:
https://github.com/carbonblack/cbapi-python/blob/master/src/cbapi/response/models/process.yaml

For the **group** key there are two type sub keys one of which should be a **format**. So the change should be from:

```
  group:
    type: string
    **type**: string
```

To;

```
  group:
    type: string
    **format**: string
```

items.title: Retrieve start time for process object
items.body:
Inspecting the Cb ThreatHunter UI requests to `processes/search_jobs/1bc14c8c-ffa8-4d39-8c51-6b13c9f8f14d/results?start=0&rows=1` (when viewing a process analysis page) shows that the JSON response contains fields such as `process_start_time`, `process_original_filename`, and `process_internal_name`.

How can this data be retrieved via the Python API? For example, the only timestamps which appear to be available on Process objects are either `backend_timestamp` or `device_timestamp`, neither of which appear to be the start time of the process.

items.title: Does the Cb ThreatHunter API cap Process search results like the UI does?
items.body: During testing in both the Cb ThreatHunter UI and Python API, we're running into cases where the UI notes '_X results. Showing Y. Refine search to view additional results_'. In one example the UI says '_3,413 results. Showing 516. Refine search to view additional results_' for the query `(process_name:cmd.exe) AND device_timestamp:[2020-05-09T18:42:44 TO 2020-06-08T18:42:44] -enriched:True`. ![Screen Shot 2020-06-08 at 20 46 23](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172588/84068382-260b0b00-a9c9-11ea-96ae-bc0ed2887ecd.png) Running the same query through the Python API returns 527 Process objects when looping over the iterator. This appears to indicate that the API is also not returning the full result set. The limitation of 527 and 516 results seems strange as a previous query (on a different Cb ThreatHunter instance) yielded the message '_12,213,072 results. Showing 18,500. Refine search to view additional results_' and a lot more results via the API as well. If the platform is able to return 18,500 results in that particular case, why is it limiting far smaller resultsets like 3,413 results to only 516? ![UI_limited_results](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/172588/84068507-5652a980-a9c9-11ea-81d3-88bc0a401c52.png) My question is, how can we be sure when running a process search via the Cb ThreatHunter Python API that we're receiving all available results and not just a small subset? Our use case is that we want to retrieve things like all PowerShell download activity and then group those results based on properties which are not available as facets in the platform (i.e. `parent_name`, `process_cmdline`, etc). Unless we can be sure we're receiving all results within the requested timeframe, the data isn't telling us the full story.

items.title: Reason for using single item lists in Process properties
items.body:
I'm hoping that someone can provide some clarity regarding why some Process properties are stored as single-item lists. See the example below:

```
...
parent_guid: N5DFVQXD-012a84da-00000c54-00000000-1d63d7dd44d...
parent_pid: 3156
process_guid: N5DFVQXD-012a84da-00000858-00000000-1d63d7dd564...
process_pid: [2136]
process_username: ['NT AUTHORITY\\SYSTEM']
process_cmdline: ['C:\\Windows\\system32\\cmd.exe  /S /D /c" ech...
...
```

Why would a Process object have more than one PID, username, or cmdline and thus require the need to store this information in a list?

Additionally, I've noticed that the `watchlist_hit` property (for non-enriched Process results) is also a list, however, Processes with multiple watchlist hits are always returned by the Python API as individual and duplicate items where the `watchlist_hit` property always contains a single watchlist ID.

For example: instead of 1 Process results for Process GUID `processGUID=N5DFVQXD-012a84da-00000084-00000000-1d63dbae1cd46ab` with a `watchlist_hit` property containing a list of 3 watchlist IDs, I'm seeing 4 identical entries for Process GUID `processGUID=N5DFVQXD-012a84da-00000084-00000000-1d63dbae1cd46ab` with a `watchlist_hit` property for each entry containing one single watchlist hit entry + one additional entry containing a blank `watchlist_hit` property.

The Cb ThreatHunter API currently has no `group_by()` function to group results together by their GUID like Cb Response has, so I'm wondering if this is expected behavior and if there is a way to have the iterator only return 1 entry per unique process GUID where the `watchlist_hit` property contains all the watchlist hit entries in a single list.

items.title: Missing Cb ThreatHunter Process properties
items.body:
When retrieving Process objects through a process search in Cb ThreatHunter certain fields aren't always present (versus being present with a `None` value):

- `process_terminated`
- `parent_guid`
- `device_internal_ip`
- `device_external_ip`

This happens at random and while `process.get('parent_guid', None)` works around these missing fields, the problem is that information such as `parent_guid` is required to correctly build the link to the process analysis page.

items.title: [BUG] Cb Defense Device objects give incorrect timestamp for datetime.datetime attributes
items.body:
**I am seeing this behaviour on: (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: MacOS 10.15.2
 - Carbon Black Product: CB Defense
 - Python Version: 3.7.3

**Describe the bug**
cbapi.psc.defense.Device have some attributes (lastContact, lastShutdownTime, etc.) that are timestamps. When these attributes are accessed they get converted to datetime.datetime objects. However, instead of being the correct datetime, they always end up evaluating to '1970-01-01 00:00:00'.

I believe this is related to the fact that Cb Defense gives timestamps in milliseconds, but the datetime library works with timestamps in seconds.

**Steps to Reproduce**
The following code reproduces the issue and highlights various behaviors handling timestamps:

> \# for the sake of this example, assume the vale of device.lastContact is 1580235662515
>
>import cbapi
>import datetime
>
>def_api = cbapi.CbDefenseAPI()
>device = def_api.select(cbapi.psc.defense.Device).first()
>
>\# timestamp is correct when printing object
>print(device) \# prints all attributes, including 'lastContact: 1580235662515'
>
>\# accessing timestamp attribute give incorrect datetime object
>print(device.lastContact) \# prints '1970-01-01 00:00:00'
>
>\# directly accessing timestamp gives correct timestamps
>print(device.__dict__['_info']['lastContact']) \# prints '1580235662515'
>
>\# directly accessing timestamp and converting from ms to seconds,
>\# then converting to timestamp give correct datetime
>print(datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(device.__dict__['_info']['lastContact']/1000)) \# prints 2020-01-28 12:21:02.515000
>
>\# not converting to seconds throws an error
>print(datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(device.__dict__['_info']['lastContact']))
>\# throws the following error:
>\# Traceback (most recent call last):
>\#   File "cbapi_bug.py", line 22, in <module>
>\#     print(datetime.datetime.fromtimestamp(device.__dict__['_info']['lastContact']))
>\# ValueError: year 52045 is out of range

**Expected behavior**
Access timestamp attributes from Cb Defense Device objects returns the correct datetime object.

**Actual behavior**
Access timestamp attributes from Cb Defense Device objects always returns a datetime object with the value '1970-01-01 00:00:00'

items.title: [BUG] max_children flag not respected in walk_children()
items.body:
**I am seeing this behavior on: (please complete the following information):**
 - OS: OS X
 - Carbon Black Product: CB Response API
 - Python Version: 2.7

**Describe the bug**
When setting the --children in the walk_children.py example script the first query to the processes API does set the `children` parameter properly, but any subsequent call for each child process sets the `children` parameter to the default 15. **Steps to Reproduce**
Run the walk_children.py with the --verbose flag and set the children to a non default value. You will see that the first API call sets the children properly but any subsequent call does not.
 
**Expected behavior**
The `children` parameter is set for all API calls.

items.title: Alert save method fails in v2 API endpoint
items.body:
When I try to update the status of an Alert object via the save method it uses the v2 API path, resulting in an "ObjectNotFoundError": ``` cbapi.errors.ObjectNotFoundError: Received 404 (Object Not Found) for https://xxxxx.my.cbcloud.de/api/v2/alert/3642f15f-e747-454c-bea2-f6bb6abfe5f8: 404 Not Found

Not Found

The requested URL was not found on the server. If you entered the URL manually please check your spelling and try again.

``` Doing a GET request to that URL results in the same error. Swapping the "v2" out for "v1" and doing a GET request results in a 405 (method not allowed) indicating that the endpoint is there at the very least. Issue [https://github.com/carbonblack/cbapi-python/issues/158](https://github.com/carbonblack/cbapi-python/issues/158) appears to be related. I will try reverting back to an older version of cbapi for now.

items.title: cbapi should allow more than 15 children fetch
items.body:
it was found that there is possibility for /api/v1/process to pass rows for children count based on query parameter "children"

So, a request http://xxx/api/v1/process/YYY/0?children=100 would return max of 100 children instead of default 15. The restriction works well for UI, however, cbapi should have a way to pass this parameter if customer is willing to do so.

walk_children.py in example script used to traverse all children of a process example:

python walk_children.py --process XXX-XXX-XXX-XXX --verbose
would run down all the children of the processes, however at depth 0, the count would be limited to 15.

PS: Issue is not raised to fix walk_children.py (its an example script on how to use cbapi) , The issue being reported is inability to utilize query param children when using cbapi to perform search.

On hacking the cbapi connection.py to hard-code adding "?children=100" in all http_request sent, I was able to get more children (PS: This is not a solution proposed)

Test Result:

Original cbapi:

[root@aman walk_children]# cat file.out_original | grep depth | rev | cut -d" " -f1 | sort | uniq -c
COUNT DEPTH
 15 0
 59 1
 87 2
 21 3
 11 4
 6 5
 2 6

After adding hack in connection.py 

[root@aman walk_children]# cat file2.out | grep depth | rev | cut -d" " -f1 | sort | uniq -c
COUNT DEPTH
 89 0
 603 1
 1096 2
 138 3
 66 4
 20 5
 6 6
 (For above tests I added following line in visitor method in walk_children.py)

`print ("Working with {0}  at depth {1}".format(proc.process_name, depth));`

CB Internal : CB-28123

items.title: "No organization key specified"
items.body: In cbapi 1.4.5, a check was added in the __init__ call of CbThreatHunterAPI (line 25-26 of file rest_api.py) to check if 'org_key' is in credentials. However if you are instantiating the client with a set of kwargs it never pops off the org_key from the kwargs in the BaseApi __init__, it only pops off url and token (line 219-227 of file connection.py). So if you instantiate a client with kwargs instead of a credentials file you will always get the No organization key specified even when passing it in to the constructor.

items.title: SDK does not seem 100% compatible with new API
items.body:
We are trying to pull alerts out of Cb Response using the following piece of code:
self.cb_conn.select(Alert).where(query_string)

query_string here is an arbitrary query with just the time and a machine hostname referenced. Example Query:

created_time:[2019-04-22T11:38:50 TO *] AND hostname:randomhostname

Example API call generated by the SDK:

 /api/v1/alert?cb.urlver=1&facet=false&q=created_time%3A%5B2019-04-22T11%3A38%3A50+TO+%2A%5D+AND+hostname%3Arandomhostname&rows=500&start=0

Example observed error:

[2019-04-22 15:55:08](WARNING) Retrying (Retry(total=4, connect=None, read=None, redirect=None, status=None)) after connection broken by 'ReadTimeoutError("HTTPSConnectionPool(host='commercial-carpet.my.carbonblack.io', port=443): Read timed out. (read timeout=120)",)': /api/v1/alert?cb.urlver=1&facet=false&q=created_time%3A%5B2019-04-22T11%3A38%3A50+TO+%2A%5D+AND+hostname%3Ausshb811988&rows=500&start=0

After looking into the API documentation and the source code of the SDK. It appears that the SDK should be using /api/v2/alert instead of /api/v1/alert. When we retried that same REST call with v2 instead, the query appeared to work. 

It appears that the SDK should be utilizing the /api/v2/alert endpoint instead of the /api/v1/alert. endpoint.

print '_sessions: ' + str(c.live_response._sessions)

A simplified version of what I am doing is below.

Is there anyway to sped this up?

```
for ml in p.modloads:
	ebin = ml.binary

	computer_count = ebin.frequency.computer_count

	print('path={}'.format(ml.path), end=', ')
	print('computer_count={}'.format(computer_count))
```

items.title: Requests for many Alerts timeout / take a long time.
items.body:
Iterating over a large set of alerts returned by query ```alert_query = cb_connection.select(Alert).where(query)``` has proved problematic recently as any request for upwards of 100 alert objects to the server would often timeout and has even resulted in the service being made unavailable for a couple of minutes due to what I assume is the operation's taxing nature on the backend.

I have found a fix that appears to not be quite so taxing on the backend, however it would require the API version for requesting alerts to be bumped from v1 to v2 ```Alert.urlobject = '/api/v2/alert'```. I've not created a pull request as I am not sure what impact this change may have on support for older version of Carbon Black.

items.title: Sensors are not paginated in deterministic order with /api/v2/sensor
items.body: Iterating through Sensors with a simple for loop ends up missing some sensors and duplicating others - due to non-deterministic sort order by default in `/api/v2/sensor` API route

items.title: Cb Response server does not properly escape non-BMP unicode in event data
items.body: Cb Response sends data like "\U0001f30e" for U+1f30e http://www.charbase.com/1f30e-unicode-earth-globe-americas instead of the UTF-8 surrogate pairs. Technically this is in violation of JSON and thus the JSON parser chokes on the input.

items.title: Live Response Timeout Exception
items.body: When calling for a live session with lr_session() and an exception can be thrown (ie timeout which is VERY common, or something else) the session is NOT closed but left in pending. Seeing as you can only have 10 sessions open by default this causes an issue.

items.title: Feature Request: Download Compressed Binary
items.body:
Using the [API](https://github.com/carbonblack/cbapi/tree/master/client_apis#apiv1binarymd5) (or the web UI), the binary you download from CarbonBlack is `.zip` compressed.

From what I can tell, the Python library automatically decompresses when it exposes the `binary.file` object. Is there any way (via Python library) to download the compressed binary directly?

items.title: Update watchlist sharing examples to use cbapi-python
items.body: See https://github.com/carbonblack/community/tree/master/cb/watchlist_sharing

items.title: Cb Response server 6.0 responds with parent_md5 of '0'*30
items.body: Current test to work around this bug is to check for a parent_md5 of '0'*32 ... apparently Cb 6 has a new behavior where it returns 30 '0''s instead...

items.title: Credentials in constructor
items.body:
The Python-API [README](https://github.com/carbonblack/cbapi-python/blob/master/README.md) does not include any information about passing options/credentials into the constructor. I thus spent an hour or more trying to get disk credentials to work in a restricted environment.

However, after looking at the code I realized it is in fact possible to pass the `url` and `token` as parameters in the `CbEnterpriseResponseAPI` constructor. **Please update the README to reflect this**

items.title: Unnecessary object requests when requesting VirusTotal information on Binaries
items.body: If a binary does not have a VirusTotal score associated with it, the document simply has no `alliance_score_virustotal` attribute (instead of a null or zero score). Therefore, when the `.virustotal` accessor attempts to read the score, it sees that the attribute doesn’t exist- which it assumes to mean that it simply hasn’t read the whole object in yet, so it makes an explicit request for the full object.

items.title: CbNetconnEvent should be extended to accept IPv6 address types
items.body: These will be represented as strings in future versions of Cb Response

items.title: CbNetconnEvent uses inet_ntop which is not available on Windows
items.body: This makes all netconns give an ip address of `0.0.0.0` - fix to use another library that's x-platform

items.title: CbNetconnEvent does not include proxy_ip
items.body: Add `proxy_ip` into the netconn event - currently missing

items.title: Facets don't work with Watchlist.search()
items.body: This is caused because the .facets() method doesn't respect the ._raw_query parameter

  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.5/dist-packages/cbapi/response/models.py", line 741, in frequency
    hostCount = self._frequency.get('hostCount', 0)
AttributeError: 'FrequencyData' object has no attribute 'get'

Interestingly, this works fine:
data=c.select(Binary)
f=data[0].frequency
print(f.computer_count)   # access it for the first time
print(f.process_count)      # second access, no exception

But I assume that this is not expected behavior. 

Regards
Adam

items.title: Issue with REST API array indexing from Cb Protection
items.body:
See issue below:

```
In [16]: p.select(Computer).where("name:WORKGROUP\\WIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI")[::]
HTTP GET /api/bit9platform/v1/computer?limit=1000&offset=0&q=name%3AWORKGROUP%5CWIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI took 0.090s (response 200)
Out[16]:
[<cbapi.protection.models.Computer: id 1> @ https://192.168.215.128,
 <cbapi.protection.models.Computer: id 2> @ https://192.168.215.128]
```

yet:

```
In [13]: p.select(Computer).where("name:WORKGROUP\\WIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI")[0]
HTTP GET /api/bit9platform/v1/computer?limit=1&offset=0&q=name%3AWORKGROUP%5CWIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI took 0.149s (response 200)
HTTP GET /api/bit9platform/v1/computer/1 took 0.010s (response 200)
Out[13]: <cbapi.protection.models.Computer: id 1> @ https://192.168.215.128

In [14]: p.select(Computer).where("name:WORKGROUP\\WIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI")[1]
HTTP GET /api/bit9platform/v1/computer?limit=2&offset=1&q=name%3AWORKGROUP%5CWIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI took 0.082s (response 200)
Out[14]: <cbapi.protection.models.Computer: id 1> @ https://192.168.215.128

In [15]: p.select(Computer).where("name:WORKGROUP\\WIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI")[2]
HTTP GET /api/bit9platform/v1/computer?limit=3&offset=2&q=name%3AWORKGROUP%5CWIN-IA9NQ1GN8OI took 0.098s (response 200)
HTTP GET /api/bit9platform/v1/computer/2 took 0.010s (response 200)
Out[15]: <cbapi.protection.models.Computer: id 2> @ https://192.168.215.128

```

items.title: Exception with `webui_link` in some models
items.body: Old models reference a `webui_link` attribute which is not always available. This should not cause an exception when "print"ing a model object.
